learning_outcomes.description: Critically appraise artworks - Critically appraise an artwork or visual representation in oral and written form and identify historical context of artworks and visual culture.

Apply history of art and aesthetics broadly - Understand key periods in art history and fundamental theories about aesthetics. Apply ideas gained from the history of art and aesthetics to diverse intellectual fields of study

Gain familiarity with visual arts industry - Be familiar with principles of arts curating and methods and principles of exhibition display.Understand fundamental terminology and methodologies used in the visual arts industry.

assessments.due_date:
23/03/2026 - 18/05/2026

To be submitted in class in Weeks 5, 7, 9, 10 and 11.
assessments.task_description:
Five worksheets with short questions on aspects of the lecture and readings will be distributed in class in weeks 5, 7, 9, 10 and 11. The worksheets will be completed individually on paper towards the end of the tutorial and handed in directly to the tutor at the end of class. Each worksheet is worth 3% of final grade. Worksheets are pass/fail: if you answer the question and submit it, you will pass. The worksheets are a hurdle requirement: a minimum of 3 of the 5 worksheets must be passed in order to pass the course overall. Students who fail to pass the 3 worksheets threshold will receive a (maximum) final grade of 3 for the entire course, regardless of performance in other assessment items.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to write a visual analysis of 800 words that uses a specific theme to describe one artwork currently on display at the Queensland Art Gallery / Gallery of Modern Art. Students must apply visual analysis techniques learnt in class to identify particular elements and aspects of the work and explain how they work together to promote the theme of their choice. Tutorial site visits to QAGOMA to view the art works and put your visual analysis skills into practice will take place in Weeks 3 and 4.

AIMS OF ASSESSMENT:

  • Create a focused and coherent theme of interpretation that is used as a frame for analysing what the artwork is intending to communicate
  • Demonstrate understanding of visual literacy and application of visual analysis elements as key evidence to support thematic argument


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. Any use of AI/MT must be acknowledged and referenced. Failure to reference or acknowledge generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This assignment will be submitted electronically via Blackboard using TurnItIn. Before submitting any assignments for this course, you must ensure you have completed UQ's compulsory online Academic Integrity Tutorial.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The final exam is in two parts: Part A (30 minutes) is a series of short image identifications. You will be required to identity each image with the artist, title, and year of work. Part B (60 minutes) is an in-class essay. You will be given three questions to choose from: select ONE of the questions to write your response. There will be 10 minutes of reading and preparation time provided at the beginning of the exam. No external materials permitted.

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: UQ is presently rolling out a new assessment tool, Inspera Assessment. Inspera Assessment provides additional functionality to complement the existing suite of digital learning tools at UQ with a greater range of question types and accessibility provisions.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

Week 2: Visual Literacy and Visual Analysis

Lecture on 'unpacking an artwork' and learning how to identify different visual elements of an image and interpret their meanings.

Week 3 Lecture: Space and Illusionism

Lecture on how space and illusionism are created in figurative and abstract works of art. Includes introduction of relevant art historical vocabulary.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3 Tutorial: QAGOMA Visual Analysis Site Visit 1

QAGOMA Visual Analysis Module 1

Tutorial will be held in the Australian galleries at the Queensland Art Gallery, Southbank. Meet your tutor in the foyer of the gallery and we will learn how to put visual analysis techniques into practice with specific works of art. During the tutorial you will be able to choose any of the art works currently on display to analyse for your first assignment.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

During the tutorial you will be able to choose any of the art works currently on display to analyse for your first assignment.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Modernism and Modern Art

Guest lecture by Dr Christian Rizzalli. Examines the explicit spirit to represent modernity in art and how it was perceived originally in Europe, and then internationally.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Art in Museums and Galleries

Lecture by Dr Amelia Barikin: historical overview of the display of art in galleries and museums, charting developments in the presentation of art to the public from the opening of the Louvre to the present.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

Meet your tutor at Queensland Art Gallery / Gallery of Modern Art, Southbank, to learn about the collections and curatorial activities of public art institutions in relation to the specific displays and exhibitions on view.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: Art and Identity

In what ways might art be used to challenge social and political hierarchies of identity? We will look at aspects of gender and sexuality with reference to art practices in Australia and internationally.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11 Lecture: What is Contemporary Art?

How do we categorise contemporary art? What is it, what forms does it take, and where can it be found? Lecture by Dr Amelia Barikin considering the art of our own time in the context of globalisation and heterogeneity.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
